Package projects.tavl

Class ThreadedAVLTree<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.tavl.ThreadedAVLTree<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The Comparable type held by the data structure.
    public class ThreadedAVLTree<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object

    ThreadedAVLTree implements threaded Adelson-Velsky-Landis (AVL) trees (shorthand: TAVL trees). These trees:

    1. Allow for efficient search, insertion and deletion in O(logn) time, by virtue of being AVL trees.
    2. Perform a full inorder traversal in O(n) time, by virtue of being threaded trees.

    Hence, two powerful ideas that we have talked about in lecture will now be combined in one data structure.

    Author:
    Jason Filippou
    See Also:
    StudentTests

      • delete

        public T delete​(T key)
        Delete the key from the data structure and return it to the caller.
        Parameters:
        key - The key to delete from the structure.
        Returns:
        The key that was removed, or null if the key was not found.

      • search

        public T search​(T key)
        Search for key in the tree. Return a reference to it if it's in there, or null otherwise.
        Parameters:
        key - The key of type T to look for in the tree.
        Returns:
        key if key is in the tree, or null otherwise.

      • height

        public int height()
        Return the height of the tree. The height of the tree is defined as the length of the longest path between the root and the leaf level. By definition of path length, a stub tree has a height of 0, and we define an empty tree to have a height of -1.
        Returns:
        The height of the tree.

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Query the tree for emptiness. A tree is empty iff it has zero keys stored.
        Returns:
        true if the tree is empty, false otherwise.

      • getRoot

        public T getRoot()
        Return the key at the tree's root node.
        Returns:
        The key at the tree's root node.

      • inorderTraversal

        public java.util.Iterator<T> inorderTraversal()
        Generate an inorder (symmetric) traversal over the tree's stored keys. This should be done by using the tree's threads, to be able to find every inorder successor in amortized constant time.
        Returns:
        A Iterator over Ts, which exposes the elements in symmetric order.
